Due to the move of the ERCS server from Solaris to Linux logins based on the user names are no longer used. The login is now the user’s Standard Employee Identiﬁer (SEID) in lower case letters.
The IRS replaced the Online 5081 (OL5081) system with the Business Entitlement Access Request System (BEARS). References to OL5081 have been replaced with BEARS.

Content from the AIMS/ERCS website was required to be moved to the Virtual Library. ERCS content was moved to the ERCS book under the Exam Systems Knowledge Base. References to the AIMS/ERCS website have been replaced with the ERCS book.
Signiﬁcant changes to this IRM are reﬂected in the table below:

) Users must be aware of the potential for UNAX violations from the use of ERCS. Data from ERCS should be accessed only for IRS business Users should promptly retrieve ERCS reports from printers or fax machines order to prevent unauthorized disclosure. For more information about UNAX, see IRM

) Audit trails are created when ERCS records are researched, added, or deleted. Research should be limited to a user’s official business needs in order to prevent unnecessary disclosure. Audit trails are also created for potential UNAX violations. These audit trails include when a user: • Inputs their own social security number (SSN). • Inputs the SSN of a spouse. • Attempts to view or update an IRS employee’s return without permis- sion. • Attempts to update a return without permission. • Inputs a name search that matches an employee’s name. (

) Per IRS security requirements, IT employees are not permitted to have to taxpayer data. No IT employee should be approved for ERCS access and any user transferred or detailed to an IT position must submit a Remove Access request to have all permission records removed. (

) For security issues concerning ERCS, including pre-requisites for ERCS access, information on completing a BEARS request, requesting temporary permission, and employee audit security features see IRM
, Security. (

) PSP has the responsibility to work with HQ Examination in the creation of Exam Plan, to ensure the ﬁeld has the correct amount and type of inventory accomplish the plan, and to monitor the work in the ﬁeld to ensure the Exam Plan will be met. In order to do this, PSP uses data from various sources including ERCS, AIMS, Summary Examination Time Transmission System (SETTS), AIMS Computer Information System (A-CIS), and Statistical Sampling Inventory Validation Listing (SSIVL). In determining which data source is the best option for a particular monitoring need it is important to derstand each system, the differences between them, and where the data in the system originates. (

4.7.4.3 ERCS Data
ERCS is an inventory control and time tracking system. It contains selected data for SB/SE and LB&I returns in the Examination stream from Status
Examination Returns Control System
to

ERCS is used to maintain group and work unit inventories and as vehicle to update AIMS. Technical time is captured on ERCS by the daily tivities performed. ERCS accepts and extracts data from a number of but the two main interfaces are with AIMS and SETTS. ERCS sends tion to AIMS on a daily basis; and information from AIMS is compared to ERCS on a weekly basis. Summary time information is extracted for roll-up each reporting cycle. (

) AIMS is the system of records for SB/SE, LB&I, Appeals, W&I, and TE/GE. contains accomplishment information for returns in the Examination stream. PSP utilizes AIMS to obtain information such as: • Location of case ﬁles. • Codes (i.e. source, project, tracking, aging reason, etc.) • Closing information (i.e. examination time, disposal code, results, • Historical information (such as prior primary business code (PBC), secondary business code (SBC), prior employee group code (EGC), status code and status date history, and opening source code). (

) AIMS records are established by: • Campus (includes automatic openings, taxpayer requests/claims, ﬁler, etc.) • PSP (includes projects, programs, CDE, etc.) • Groups (when picking up related returns) (

) The main differences between AIMS data and ERCS data are: • ERCS only includes data for SB/SE and LB&I. • ERCS contains information for penalties. • ERCS allows for inventory control for activities that are not return related (such as offers in compromise, interest abatement, etc.) • ERCS contains a break down of daily time charges by employees. • ERCS provides inventory control for returns by associating returns an examiner and providing current, on demand reports. (
) For more information regarding AIMS see IRM
, Audit Information ment System (AIMS) - Validity and Consistency. (
) SSIVL is a system which allows AIMS data to be downloaded by Business Operating Division (BOD), Area, function, etc. and used to generate reports. (

) The SSIVL data is AIMS data with the addition of the three employee cation (ID) ﬁelds from ERCS (Group or PSP, Centralized Case Processing (CCP) and Review). Up-to-date AIMS data is sent to the ERCS server each weekend. (

) AIMS Assignee Code (AAC) information recorded in ERCS is used to the support area responsible for returns listed on the area’s SSIVL. Data is extracted by support area and sent to a server at the Detroit Computing for each area. The A/E staff imports the SSIVL data into a Microsoft Access database. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) PSP uses CDE to classify SB/SE returns, establish the AIMS database, and deliver returns to the ﬁeld. Once a return is selected, CDE sends a to establish the return on AIMS in a PSP CDE EGC. Over the following weekend during AIMS to ERCS processing, the AIMS record is added to ERCS if it has not been previously added. (
) When the AIMS record is fully established, a CDE user assigns the return to the examination group on CDE which sends a status code, status date, and EGC update to AIMS. (

) Over the following weekend during AIMS to ERCS processing, the AIMS for the examination group overwrites the PSP CDE AAC, as well as the code and status date, on ERCS. It is critical the AAC on ERCS be as a PSP CDE EGC so this process will work. Otherwise the return will on the ERCS AAC Difference Report. See Exhibit
for a list of PSP standardized CDE EGCs with descriptions. (

) An employee audit occurs when the tax return of an IRS employee is examined. ERCS provides special security features for employee returns audit. When any of the following events occur an audit trail is created and ERCS employee audit alert is generated: • A user enters their SSN or the SSN of a spouse or former spouse (if joint return was ﬁled) • The source code on a return is changed to or from Source Code

, Employee Returns • The Employee Audit indicator is turned on or off on a return • An unauthorized user attempts to access an employee’s return • A user attempts to add an employee return to ERCS for an who should not be audited in the same area • A employee’s return is on AIMS and during AIMS to ERCS the program attempts to add the return to ERCS in an area where employee should not be audited • The addition of a high proﬁle employee return to ERCS (such as the security officer) (

The AAC is used to identify the location of returns. In PSP the AAC is used to further classify returns into speciﬁc programs. The AAC is comprised of three ﬁelds:
PBC (three digits) identifying the SB/SE Area or LB&I Practice Area SBC (ﬁve digits) identifying the Territory. In PSP this is always 87700 EGC (four digits) identifying the group or program
Generally EGCs used in PSP include the following:

EGC Location Description 1000-1099 Campus RA area work physically located in the campus; 1000 is used for RA PSP** returns awaiting classiﬁcation; 1066 is used for RA returns in Cen- tralized Files. 2000-2099 Campus TCO area work physically located in the campus; 2000 is used for PSP** TCO returns awaiting classiﬁcation; 2050 is used for TCO returns in Centralized Files and Scheduling. 1997 In-transit LB&I transfers in from another area for RA returns. 1998 In-transit SB/SE and WEIIC (PBC 330) transfers in from another area for RA returns. 2998 In-transit SB/SE and WEIIC transfers in from another area for TCO returns. 1850-1999* Area PSP** Area office RA PSP. 2850-2999* Area PSP** Area office TCO PSP.

When there is a need to establish a new AAC in PSP, the A/E staff adds the AAC using the area PSP range and identiﬁes the code as either a PSP code or a CDE code. Returns in an AAC identiﬁed on ERCS as a campus AAC are treated differently when returns on AIMS and ERCS are compared.

When a return is on ERCS in a PSP AAC and AIMS is updated to another PSP EGC or to a group AAC, AIMS will not overwrite the ERCS AAC. The return will be listed as an error on the AAC Difference Report. These changes should be made on ERCS and not AIMS.
a return is on ERCS in a CDE PSP AAC and AIMS is updated to another PSP EGC or to a group AAC, will overwrite the ERCS AAC. CDE PSP AACs are area codes and PSP has full inventory control of on ERCS.
See the Contacts page of the ERCS book for EGC, LB&I and A/E Staff contact lists.

Action codes are used on ERCS to add another level of inventory control for PSP. The action code is an only code that can be locally deﬁned (by area or by LB&I). When an action code is input on a return, a purge date is either set by the ERCS program or input by the user. Changes in the local deﬁnitions of action codes should be coordinated with the A/E staff.

Action codes may be added or updated on returns in the Tax Auditor menu or the Correct or Display Records menu. Reports in the Tax Auditor menu display records using these codes. The Daily Report and the Group Purge Report can be modiﬁed by the local A/E staff to include or exclude returns with particular action codes. However, any changes to these reports impact PSP in the entire area. Refer to the Codes chapter of the ERCS PSP Handbook for more information about these codes.

Suspense types are used in conjunction with action dates in ERCS when follow-up is necessary, but the action may not take place for days, weeks or months. When a suspense type is added to a return, the return may be updated to a status code and the action date may be set based on the number of days as shown in the table below. If the program does not set the action date, the user must enter it. If a new suspense type is needed it should be coordinated with the A/E staff. New suspense types are added by the HQ ERCS analysts. Refer to the Codes chapter of the ERCS PSP Handbook for more information about the suspense type. Refer to the In- ventory Reports chapter of the ERCS PSP Handbook for information about the Suspense Report which is used to monitor returns in these codes.
Note: PSP suspense types are in the 300 to 399 range.
